prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I make my gf start paying some of the bills over a single incident?
Gf and I live together.   She only works part time.    I pay all the rent and bill.  I never minded it until last night. 

We went to grab some take out and I realized I left my wallet in my work pants.  I told her she’d have to get it.   Her attitude about the whole thing was so ugly.   At first she couldn’t believe it and asked me if I was serious in this almost disgusted tone.  She acted so put out by it. 

It was some fucking take out.  Under $40.  I pay EVERYTHING.  I understand she only makes a little, but that little is probably a lot with no expenses.   I know it was only one incident, but I haven’t been able to get it out of my head since.   It’s really rubbing my the wrong way.  She wouldn’t be able to pay a lot of the bills, but I feel like it’s time for her to start carrying her weight.  Just out of principal.  
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the author of the given situation is in the wrong. The scenario involves a couple living together where the author, who pays all the bills, wants his girlfriend to start contributing after an incident where she had to pay for takeout. The user thinks the author is in the wrong and wants to know if that's accurate.

First, I need to analyze the situation. The key points are: the author pays all the bills, the girlfriend works part-time, and the author is upset about her attitude when she had to pay for a $40 takeout. He wants her to start paying some bills, even though she can't contribute much. 

Now, considering fairness and communication. The author has been paying everything, which might be his choice, but the girlfriend's reaction was negative. The author is now holding that single incident against her and wants her to start contributing, which might not be fair. Maybe the author didn't communicate his expectations earlier. If he never discussed splitting costs or contributions, expecting her to suddenly start without prior conversation could be unfair. Also, the amount was small, and her part-time job might not allow her to contribute much. The author's reaction seems disproportionate. So, maybe the author is in the wrong because he's punishing her for a minor incident and not considering their communication or her financial situation. Alternatively, some might argue that the author is right to want shared responsibility. But since the user thinks the author is in the wrong, I need to see which side is more justified. The author's anger over a small incident and using it as a reason to make her pay bills without prior discussion might indicate that he's overreacting. Therefore, the answer is likely A (the author is in the wrong).
